signature: Sarah Duncan, Charge Midwife, Aberdeen Maternity Hospital, NHS Grampian
body:
Firstly may I offer my congratulations to you and your husband on the birth of your baby daughter, and thank you for taking the time to provide us with feedback on your experiences at AMH.  
I am sorry that there was a delay in transferring you to the Midwives Unit following your second examination. Entonox is usually available in Triage and you are absolutely right to say that it should have been made accessible to you in order to help you cope whilst waiting for the birthing pool. We will take this forward as a point of learning. Regardless of how busy Triage is, it is important that women in established labour are cared for, and that pain relief is prioritised if there is a delay in transferring to a more appropriate setting.  
I am delighted to hear of your positive birth experience at the Midwives Unit. I completely agree that Kay is an exceptional midwife and I know that she will be thrilled to receive your feedback.  
Thank you once again,  
Sarah Duncan  
Interim Lead Midwife  
Midwives Unit  
AMH

signature: Riverside Surgery
body:
Dear OneOfYou
Thank you for your feedback. Firstly, please accept our sincere apologies for any distress caused by this situation and that you felt we did not meet the standards expected of us as it is never our intention to upset our patients.  

We will use this information as part of a review and discuss the issues raised with the reception team. This will give the team an opportunity to reflect on their actions and understand what they could have done differently to prevent these types of incidents occurring in future. 

Unfortunately, recently we have had several occasions where we have had limited staff due to covid isolation rules for healthcare workers. This impacted on how many staff were available to answer telephone calls and caused significant delays to patients queueing on the telephone. Hopefully we may soon see things improve as the guidance changes.

Once again, please accept our apologies for your dissatisfaction of our service. However, if you need to speak to your doctor, have any further feedback or alternative suggestions in the meantime please let us know.

signature: Dishley Grange Medical Practice
body:
Dear Patient, 
We are very sorry to hear that your recent experience with Dishley Grange Medical Practice did not reflect the standards in which we aim to work.
Our patient’s experience is of paramount importance to us, and we would like to thank you for bringing your concerns to our attention.
Our phone lines tend to be at its busiest between the hours of 8-9am and the practice can receive up to 300 calls just in this first hour. We ask patients that require a routine appointment to call in after this time to help relieve pressures off the appointment system.
Alternatively, the practice has also introduced the ‘Queue Buster’ option. This option allows you to disconnect your call but will hold your position in the queue. Once a member of our team becomes available the automated system will call you back on your dialled line to connect you with a member of our team.
It is our hope that this system, when utilised effectively will help minimise the pressures off our phone lines and help patients with our queueing system.
Due to demand in service, our appointments can get booked very quickly. This is due to changes at a national level, unfortunately currently there is little we can do to increase the number of appointments that we offer as this is sadly beyond our control.
Nevertheless, we will continue to review our appointment system to see if we can improve the way in which our service is offered.
Again, we are very sorry for your experience, and we would like to thank you for your valuable feedback and allowing us the opportunity to reflect on the service that we offer.
Yours Sincerely,
Dishley Grange Medical Practice
Patient Service and Quality Team.

body:
Thank you for replying, since my initial post my neck spasm has cleared up. I had an appointment at the rheumatology department at Glasgow Royal Infirmary as I also have bones chipped off from my patella (Loose Bodies) the cartilage has also worn away. This was confirmed via X-ray and an MRI scan. After getting an appointment to see a surgeon I mentioned to the doctor that I had left sided hip pain as well. He said it was probably over compensation for the injury in my right knee.  
A week later the pain in my left thigh was so severe I couldn’t walk so I had to call the surgery to ask for another home visit. This time a doctor came out examined me at home and confirmed that my thigh muscle was in constant spasm and that’s why it was so painful. She prescribed 5 days of muscle relaxants and said that should be fine.  
I’m now on day 6 and although the pain has eased slightly it is still very painful and I’m having to use crutches to get about the house and even that is very painful.  
I’m actually afraid to call my surgery again after the first incident. I’m still housebound, can’t drive my car or walk to a shop but the first incident has made me so anxious that I think they will either not believe me or not come out after having the same problem in two different places in a month.  
I just want to make you aware how patients with chronic illnesses feel intimidated when calling about other problems.  
I’d rather try and get a lift to A&E than have to call back.  
Thank you for listening.

Dear kels0787 - thank you for providing this feedback and sorry for the delay in responding.  
We apologise to you that as the next of kin you were not contacted with an update on what was happening to your grandmother, this must have been a very distressing time for you and your family. You had mentioned your grandmother was confused, we do allow a family member to remain with someone in the emergency department if they have confusion or a communication problem.  
We have quite a few telephones in the department and I assure you staff do answer them, I am not sure what happened on this occasion.  
I have shared your comments with the sister to remind our staff they must contact next of kin with an update. We hope your grandmother is recovering.  
Kind Regards  
Paul Smyth

body:
Dear Shagq75 - thank you for this feedback and apologies for the delay in responding.  
Thank you for your kind words of praise for the A&E staff. Unfortunately the long waiting time is primarily caused by the A&E being unable to get patients waiting on an admission bed up to the wards as there are no beds available. This results in long waits to be seen and delayed ambulance offloads.  
There are vending machines at the main hospital entrance and a shop in close proximity to ED. The small size and footprint of the emergency department waiting room does not have any space for vending machines  
When we have patients waiting on admission to the wards, meals are sent from the canteen on trays for staff to distribute.  
We hope you are recovering  
Best wishes  
Paul

signature: Collingwood Surgery
body:
Dear valued patient,

As the Practice Manager i'd like to thank you for your feedback. Patient feedback good or bad is incredibly important to us and helps us to improve our services. 

I'm sorry that you have had difficulty in getting through to us. The practice has recently experienced unprecedented demand and we will often receive high volumes of calls, particularly in a morning or in the period leading up to a public holiday. To mitigate these times of high call volume we installed a queuing system to make it fairer to our patients as before this new system you would just receive an engaged tone once the lines were full and would need to try multiple times to get through which I hope you'd agree is not a fair way of doing things. Additionally, to ensure people aren't waiting in the queue for a long time we have installed a "callback" feature which keeps your place in the queue and calls you back once you reach the front of the queue, allowing you to go about your day without waiting on the phone.

Also, if you have an enquiry in future that doesn't require an appointment you can do this using the E-Consult service at the link below or the NHS App. Questions submitted on this system come directly and securely to a member of staff here and then are actioned appropriately. 

https://collingwoodsurgery.webgp.com/

Although you feel that the difficulties you've had is down to the merger with Appleby Surgery I can assure you it isn't. We actually have more reception and admin staff per patient than we did pre-merger so the difficulties you have faced are indicative of the pressure that all practices in the area are currently under. 

Once again i'm sorry that you've had difficulty getting through on the occasions you mention. If you would like to email the practice and identify yourself i'd be more than happy to discuss this with you in more detail over the phone or in person. Our email address is collingwood.surgery@nhs.net

Kind regards,

David Pierce
Practice Manager

Dear Patient 
Thank you for your feedback regarding booking of a routine appointment.We are regularly reviewing our systems in accordance with the easing of covid related restrictions; at present all appointments are booked for the same day to minimise cancellations where staff are suddenly needing to isolate as per NHS guidelines.Initially the routine appointment would be a telephone consultation with a GP that day and then if necessary they would arrange a convenient time for you to come into the practice for a face to face consultation. Please be assured that where patients have urgent needs we have specific allocated doctors every day who will see these patients that same day. Patient Liaison Officer
The Westgate Practice

signature: The Doctors House
body:
Dear Patient 

The doctor referred you for your Ultrasound on 26th November; we sent the request on the same day. Unfortunately, you had to wait over 2 months for your scan. 

You had the scan on the 4th February and we received the report the following week. As soon as the medical secretary received the report, she sent an internal message to the doctor who referred you to the review your report. 

The doctor only works Tuesday and Fridays and therefore she reviewed it on the 11th February, and she sent you the text asking you to book a routine appointment. If there was an urgent need to doctor would have called you on the day. That morning you also had an appointment with our Pharmacist who tried to reassure you when you asked about your Ultrasound results.

You state that you offered an advance appointment on the 11th April, as far our records show you were initially you booked for an appointment on the 5th April which you changed to the 11th April as you was going to be out of the country.  

I would like to highlight that we have increased the number of receptionist team members from 2 to 3 so that we can manage the increased call demand. I would also like to point out that our patient population size has decreased over the last 2 years.   

I hope the response addresses your concerns listed in your comments, if you need any additional information or support please contact me 

Regards
The Practice Manager

signature: The Doctors House

I apologise that you feel you received a poor service from us.

I am pleased to see that your daughter was seen by our doctor the next day. 

I hope the response addresses your concerns, if you need any additional information or support please contact me.

Regards
The Practice Manager

Dear Sir / Madam 

Thank you for your feedback 

The demand for appointments during the pandemic has been very high; throughout the pandemic, we have kept our door open for our patients. We have a number of on the day emergency appointments available, we split these evenly for patients who queue at the surgery or call on the phone. 

I understand that you have relied on the 111 and the Hub service, please note 111 have a number of appointment slots that they can book emergency patients directly onto our system. Additionally any consultation that you have had with HUB service is directly sent to our clinical system so that your records are kept updated.

Please note, we also offer econsults, which are online consultations for our patients. This allows patients to submit their symptoms or requests to us electronically and offers around the clock NHS self-help information, signposting to services, and a symptom checker. 

I hope the response addresses your concerns listed in your comments, if you need any additional information or support please contact me 

Regards
The Practice Manager

We have increased the number of receptionist from 2 to 3 per shift to answer the increased call demand. We also ask patients not to be on the line too long otherwise it has a knock on effect to other patient calls.

This year we also made changes to our telephone system, with one of the improvements being that the queue system now highlights what number you are on the queue. The music is standard background music provided by our telephone company. 

We have a number of on the day emergency appointments available, we split these evenly for patients who queue at the surgery or call on the phone. 

You can also the 111 and the Hub service on 0203 770 1888, please note 111 have a number of appointment slots that they can book emergency patients directly onto our system. signature: The Doctors House
body:
Dear Patient

I apologise for the experience you have had, as I do not have your name I have not been able to investigate your comments. 

The demand for appointments during the pandemic has been very high; throughout the pandemic, we have kept our door open for our patients. We have a number of on the day emergency appointments available, we split these evenly for patients who queue at the surgery or call on the phone. 

We have increased the number of receptionist from 2 to 3 per shift to answer the increased call demand. We also ask patients not to be on the line too long otherwise it has a knock on effect to other patient calls. All our calls are recorded and are reviewed if a customer makes a complaint about the receptionist. 

You can also the 111 and the Hub service on 0203 770 1888, please note 111 have a number of appointment slots that they can book emergency patients directly onto our system. Additional any consultation that you have with HUB service is directly sent to our clinical system so that your records are kept updated.

Our econsult clinical responses are monitored and have to be responded to within 2 workings days. 

Our blood test results are not sent by text unless you have requested these to be sent to you. All blood test results received are reviewed, addressed and filed by a doctor.

You can contact me and once I have your name I can fully investigate your comments.

I am available to discuss your comments, please contact me at the surgery.

Regards
The Practice Manager
